$MSFT $COIN

Shares of U.S. based tech giant $MSFT dropped -3.94% on Monday at $285.26, with a market cap of $2.23T, on concerns about growth for Office 365. IDC data show that global PC shipments fell -5.1% from a year ago in Q1, following the spike in demand that resulted from the Covid-19 pandemic. The stock remains -15.18% in 2022, but still up +10.36% year on year.

$MSFT shows a strong growth in EPS. Over the last 5 years, the EPS has been growing by 23.63% yearly. https://www.chartmill.com/stock/quote/MSFT/fundamental-analysis?key=92318c9b-cb66-4932-8e30-5564fa1dd6a6&utm_source=stocktwits&utm_medium=FA&utm_content=MSFT&utm_campaign=social_tracking

$MSFT Fkg  annal y s t s:
“Pessimistic analyst commentary put pressure on Microsoft (MSFT). The stock dropped almost 4% in midday trading after UBS predicted a "gentle deceleration" in growth of the firm's Office 365 product.

UBS maintained its Buy rating and $360 price target on the software giant. However, the firm argued that already high penetration, partly related to accelerated growth during the pandemic, will likely lead to slower expansion in the future.”

👉 $TSLA : Tesla stock skidded 4.8% Monday, adding to Friday's 3% decline. Shares of the EV giant finished Monday about 15% away from a cup-with-handle's 1,152.97 buy 

👉 $AAPL : Apple shares moved down 2.55% Monday, further below a 176.75 buy point in a double-bottom base. The stock is close to triggering the 7%-8% loss-cutting sell rule. Along with that double-bottom entry, a handle buy point is also in play at 179.71. On the downside, AAPL stock gave up its 50-day support level Monday, indicating further weakness is likely.

👉 $MSFT : Microsoft tumbled 3.9% Monday, as shares fall further below their 50-and 200-day lines. The stock is nearly 20% off its 52-week high.
